content: William Sidney Mount was a talented musician who designed and patented his own hollow-backed violin, which he called the 'cradle of harmony'.
source: The Long Island Museum. 'The Cradle of Harmony: William Sidney Mount's Violin'.

content: Mount's depiction of a Black man at the center of the negotiation was a subtly progressive statement for its time.
source: Frankenstein, Alfred. 'William Sidney Mount.' Harry N. Abrams, 1975.

content: Mount used a portable, wheeled studio that he could roll around his Long Island property to capture the perfect lighting for his outdoor scenes.
source: Johnson, Ole. 'William Sidney Mount: Painter of American Life.' American Art Journal, 1974.

content: The two small figures in the foreground are portraits of the artist, Asher B. Durand, and his close friend, the famous poet William Cullen Bryant.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Beeches'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/10796

content: Before becoming a landscape painter, Durand was the country's most famous engraver, known for his engraving of the 'Declaration of Independence'.
source: Howat, John K. 'American Paradise: The World of the Hudson River School.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1987.

content: Durand abandoned his highly successful career as an engraver in his forties to devote himself fully to landscape painting after a trip to the Adirondacks.
source: Lawall, David B. 'Asher Brown Durand: His Art and Art Theory in Relation to His Times.' Garland, 1977.

content: Famed mystery novelist Agatha Christie helped clean this ivory after its excavation, reportedly using her own face cream to preserve the delicate material.
source: Mallowan, Max. 'Mallowan's Memoirs'. Dodd, Mead, 1977.

content: This plaque is famously nicknamed the 'Mona Lisa of Nimrud' due to the subject's enigmatic and captivating smile.
source: Mallowan, Max. 'Nimrud and Its Remains.' Collins, 1966.

content: This pendant was found in a hoard of objects near the Iran-Afghanistan border, suggesting it was part of a treasure hidden in antiquity.
source: Aruz, Joan, ed. 'Art of the First Cities.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2003.

content: The bull's muscular form was created using repoussé, a technique where the metal is hammered from the reverse side to create a design in relief.
source: Aruz, Joan, ed. 'Art of the First Cities.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2003.

content: This clay cylinder was a foundation deposit, intended to be buried in the walls of the temple of the sun god Shamash in the city of Sippar.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Cylinder of Nebuchadnezzar II'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/321676

content: The biblical story of Nebuchadnezzar's madness is not found in any Babylonian records, which portray him as a successful and pious ruler.
source: Beaulieu, Paul-Alain. 'The Reign of Nabonidus, King of Babylon, 556-539 B.C.' Yale University Press, 1989.

content: The cylinder was never seen by humans after its burial until it was rediscovered by archaeologist Hormuzd Rassam in 1881.
source: Reade, Julian. 'Mesopotamia.' British Museum Press, 1991.

content: The silver inlay on these stirrups forms an intricate pseudo-inscription, designed to look like writing but purely for decorative effect.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Pair of Stirrups'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/29318

content: Crafted from iron, the stirrups were decorated using damascening, a process where silver wire is hammered into engraved grooves.
source: Ward, Rachel. 'Islamic Metalwork.' British Museum Press, 1993.

content: This armor was made at the royal workshops at Greenwich, founded by Henry VIII to stop English nobles from having to buy superior armor from Germany.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Field Armor of Sir James Scudamore'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/22139

content: Sir James Scudamore wore this armor in 1586 to honor Queen Elizabeth I's champion at his retirement ceremony from the tilt yard.
source: Strong, Roy. 'The Cult of Elizabeth: Elizabethan Portraiture and Pageantry.' University of California Press, 1977.

content: The armor was designed to be interchangeable, with extra pieces (an 'exchange') allowing it to be adapted for different forms of tournament combat.
source: LaRocca, Donald J. 'The Royal Armouries at Greenwich 1515-1649: A History of Its Technology.' Royal Armouries, 2011.

content: This plaque was one of hundreds that decorated the pillars of the royal palace in the Kingdom of Benin, arranged to narrate the kingdom's history.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Plaque: Warrior and Attendants'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/316393

content: The brass for this plaque was acquired through trade with Portugal in the form of 'manillas,' a type of bracelet used as currency.
source: Ezra, Kate. 'Royal Art of Benin: The Perls Collection in The Metropolitan Museum of Art.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1992.

content: This plaque was forcibly removed from the palace by British forces during the Punitive Expedition of 1897 and its ownership remains highly contested.
source: Hicks, Dan. 'The Brutish Museums: The Benin Bronzes, Colonial Violence and Cultural Restitution.' Pluto Press, 2020.

content: The 'Buli Master' is not a single person but likely a workshop style, named after the village of Buli where the first examples were identified.
source: Neyt, François. 'Luba: To the Sources of the Zaire.' Editions Dapper, 1994.

content: In Luba culture, these seats of power were so sacred they were not for sitting, but were wrapped in cloth and guarded by an official.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Seat'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/314034

content: The female figure is not a portrait but an idealized representation of the female body as a vessel for royal power and spiritual secrets.
source: Roberts, Mary Nooter, and Allen F. Roberts, eds. 'Memory: Luba Art and the Making of History.' Museum for African Art, 1996.

content: The sanza, or thumb piano, is a personal instrument played to accompany storytelling or to pass the time while walking.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Sanza'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/316173

content: The resonating chamber of this Chokwe sanza is a hollowed-out gourd, which amplifies the sound of the plucked metal keys.
source: Bastin, Marie-Louise. 'La Sculpture Tshokwe.' A. & F. Chaffin, 1982.

content: This carved stone relief, known as a lintel, would have been set above a doorway in a royal Maya structure at the city of Yaxchilan.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Lintel 25 of Structure 23, Yaxchilan'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/313240

content: The relief depicts a royal bloodletting ritual, where the queen, Lady Xoc, pulls a thorn-lined rope through her tongue to conjure a vision.
source: Schele, Linda, and Mary Ellen Miller. 'The Blood of Kings: Dynasty and Ritual in Maya Art.' Kimbell Art Museum, 1986.

content: The hieroglyphic text not only names the figures but also precisely dates the event to October 28, 709 A.D.
source: Martin, Simon, and Nikolai Grube. 'Chronicle of the Maya Kings and Queens.' Thames & Hudson, 2008.

content: The exact meaning of these 'smiling figures' from the Veracruz culture is unknown, but they may be linked to rituals involving intoxicating pulque.
source: Pool, Christopher A. 'Olmec Archaeology and Early Mesoamerica.' Cambridge University Press, 2007.

content: The flattened forehead of the figure reflects the practice of intentional cranial modification, a mark of elite status in many Mesoamerican cultures.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Smiling Figure'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/313386

content: This mask was created by hammering a single sheet of gold alloy over a wooden form, a technique known as repoussé.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Funerary Mask'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/309959

content: The dangles hanging from the mask's earrings and nose ornament would have shimmered and made noise when the funerary bundle was moved.
source: Jones, Julie, and Heidi King. 'Gold of the Americas.' The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin, 2002.

content: This massive mural was painstakingly removed from a monastery in Shanxi province, China, in the 1920s to save it from local turmoil.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Paradise of Bhaishajyaguru'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/42716

content: The central figure is Bhaishajyaguru, the Medicine Buddha, who was revered for his power to heal physical and spiritual sickness.
source: Leidy, Denise Patry. 'The Art of Buddhism: An Introduction to Its History and Meaning.' Shambhala, 2008.

content: Ikkyū Sōjun was a famous Zen Buddhist monk known for his eccentric behavior, sharp wit, and for frequenting brothels and writing erotic poetry.
source: Sanford, James H. 'Zen-Man Ikkyū.' Shambhala, 1981.

content: This scroll is a 'Gasan,' a type of Japanese artwork that combines painted imagery with poetic inscriptions.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Portrait of the Zen Priest Ikkyū Sōjun'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/897102

content: Ikkyū was the illegitimate son of an emperor and was sent to a monastery as a child to remove him from court politics.
source: Covell, Stephen G. 'Japanese Temple Buddhism: Worldliness in a Religion of Renunciation.' University of Hawaii Press, 2005.

content: Tanomura Chokunyū was a leading artist of the Nanga school, which was inspired by the scholarly, amateur painting traditions of China.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Marvelous Landscapes of the Four Seasons'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/78594

content: These paintings were designed as fusuma (sliding door panels), meaning they would have formed a panoramic, room-encompassing landscape.
source: Takeuchi, Melinda. 'Taisho Arts in the Realm of the Literati.' University of Hawaii Press, 1991.

content: The vibrant purple color of this dress comes from an aniline dye, one of the first synthetic dyes, which revolutionized the fashion industry in the 1860s.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Evening dress'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/159209

content: The massive, bell-shaped skirt was supported by a cage crinoline, a steel-hooped undergarment that led to numerous satirical cartoons and tragic accidents.
source: Waugh, Norah. 'Corsets and Crinolines.' Routledge, 1954.

content: The evening dress was likely made for a wealthy American client trying to emulate the height of Parisian fashion set by Empress Eugénie.
source: Coleman, Elizabeth Ann. 'The Opulent Era: Fashions of Worth, Doucet and Pingat.' Thames & Hudson, 1989.

content: Joseph Marie Vien was a pioneer of the Neoclassical style and later became First Painter to King Louis XVI.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Arts: A Design for a Ceiling'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/382503

content: This allegorical drawing shows figures representing painting, sculpture, and architecture paying homage to a bust of Minerva, the goddess of wisdom.
source: Kalnein, Wend von, and Michael Levey. 'Art and Architecture of the Eighteenth Century in France.' Penguin Books, 1972.

content: This print commemorates a real event: a sperm whale that beached itself near the Dutch town of Beverwijk in 1598, attracting huge crowds.
source: Schama, Simon. 'The Embarrassment of Riches: An Interpretation of Dutch Culture in the Golden Age.' Alfred A. Knopf, 1987.

content: In the 17th century, beached whales were often interpreted as divine omens, portending war, plague, or political upheaval.
source: Daston, Lorraine, and Katharine Park. 'Wonders and the Order of Nature, 1150-1750.' Zone Books, 2001.

content: The artist, Jacob Matham, was the stepson and pupil of the famous Dutch artist Hendrick Goltzius, from whom he learned his engraving technique.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Whale Stranded between Scheveningen and Katwijk'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/349137

content: This painting is potent propaganda, showing Napoleon rebuilding a city that had been severely punished for rebelling against the central government.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Napoleon I Re-establishing the City of Lyon'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/910609

content: Pierre-Henri Révoil was a leading painter of the 'Troubadour style,' which romanticized scenes from French history.
source: Chaudonneret, Marie-Claude. 'Fleury Richard et Pierre Révoil: la peinture troubadour.' Arthena, 1980.

content: The painting was commissioned by the city of Lyon itself, in a gesture of gratitude and loyalty to Napoleon for its reconstruction.
source: Lajer-Burcharth, Ewa. 'Necklines: The Art of Jacques-Louis David after the Terror.' Yale University Press, 1999.

content: Yuya and his wife Tjuyu were non-royals who rose to great prominence as the in-laws of Pharaoh Amenhotep III.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Shabti of Yuya'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/548343

content: Shabtis were magical figurines placed in tombs to perform manual labor for the deceased in the afterlife, one for every day of the year.
source: Taylor, John H. 'Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt.' British Museum Press, 2001.

content: This red granite head of Mentuhotep III was likely part of a full-body statue from the king's mortuary temple at Deir el-Bahri.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Head of King Mentuhotep III'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/545879

content: Mentuhotep III's reign during the Middle Kingdom was short, but he is known for launching a successful expedition to the land of Punt.
source: Callender, Gae. 'The Middle Kingdom Renaissance (c. 2055-1650 BC)' in 'The Oxford History of Ancient Egypt.' Oxford University Press, 2000.

content: This stela comes from the tomb chapel of Dedu, a military official who held the title 'First Bowman of the Ruler'.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Stela of the First Bowman Dedu and His Family'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/544346

content: The figures are depicted smelling lotus flowers, which symbolized rebirth and regeneration in ancient Egyptian culture.
source: Manniche, Lise. 'An Ancient Egyptian Herbal.' University of Texas Press, 1989.

content: The painting's vivid yellow background, originally brighter, has faded over time due to the chemical instability of the chrome yellow pigment Van Gogh used.
source: The Van Gogh Museum. 'Fading colors, explained.'

content: This painting is double-sided; on the back is a study for another famous work, 'The Potato Eaters,' done five years earlier.
source: Van Heugten, Sjraar. 'Van Gogh: The Work of a Lifetime.' BAI, 2011.

content: His brother Theo's wife, Jo van Gogh-Bonger, was instrumental in building Vincent's posthumous fame by tirelessly promoting his work and letters.
source: Naifeh, Steven, and Gregory White Smith. 'Van Gogh: The Life.' Random House, 2011.

content: The artist used the handle of his brush to scratch into the wet paint, a technique called sgraffito, to create the texture of his curly hair.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Rembrandt, Self-Portrait'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/437397

content: This self-portrait was painted a few years after Rembrandt declared bankruptcy, a period of financial ruin but intense artistic creativity.
source: Schama, Simon. 'Rembrandt's Eyes.' Alfred A. Knopf, 1999.

content: The pose, with his hand on his hip and a challenging gaze, directly imitates famous Renaissance portraits by artists like Raphael and Titian.
source: White, Christopher. 'Rembrandt by Himself.' Yale University Press, 1999.

content: Seurat died suddenly at age 31, possibly from diphtheria, just a year after completing his masterpiece based on this final study.
source: Herbert, Robert L. 'Georges Seurat, 1859-1891.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1991.

content: This is the final and most comprehensive study for Seurat's monumental masterpiece, 'A Sunday on La Grande Jatte,' now at the Art Institute of Chicago.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Study for A Sunday on La Grande Jatte'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/437658

content: The painting's border, composed of colored dots, was added by Seurat later to create a visual transition between the scene and the frame.
source: Rewald, John. 'Seurat: A Biography.' Harry N. Abrams, 1990.

content: The virtue of Temperance is shown pouring water from one vessel to another, symbolizing the dilution of wine and the avoidance of excess.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Temperance'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/204806

content: Giovanni Caccini was a rival of the more famous sculptor Giambologna, and his work represents a more classical and restrained Florentine style.
source: Avery, Charles. 'Giambologna: The Complete Sculpture.' Phaidon Press, 1987.

content: The sculpture was originally created for the palace of a Florentine senator, intended as a moral reminder for those in power.
source: Paolozzi Strozzi, Beatrice, and Dimitrios Zikos, eds. 'The Springtime of the Renaissance: Sculpture and the Arts in Florence, 1400-60.' Mandragora, 2013.

content: This sculpture depicts a scene from Dante's 'Inferno,' where Count Ugolino and his descendants starve to death in a locked tower.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Ugolino and His Sons'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/204812

content: Rodin saw this sculpture in Rome and was so profoundly influenced by it that he later created his own version of the same subject.
source: Le Normand-Romain, Antoinette. 'The Bronzes of Rodin: Catalogue of Works in the Musée Rodin.' Musée Rodin, 2007.

content: Carpeaux used his own face as the model for the anguished expression of Count Ugolino, working from his reflection in a mirror.
source: Draper, James David, and Edouard Papet. 'The Passions of Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2014.

content: This sculpture depicts the satyr Marsyas from Greek mythology, just after he has been flayed alive for losing a music contest to the god Apollo.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Marsyas'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/211486

content: The sculpture's extreme emotion and twisting pose are hallmarks of the High Baroque style, designed to provoke a strong reaction from the viewer.
source: Haskell, Francis. 'Patrons and Painters: A Study in the Relations Between Italian Art and Society in the Age of the Baroque.' Yale University Press, 1980.

content: Balthasar Permoser was the leading court sculptor in Dresden, Germany, famous for his dramatic and technically brilliant works for Augustus the Strong.
source: Asche, Sigfried. 'Balthasar Permoser: Leben und Werk.' Deutscher Verlag für Kunstwissenschaft, 1978.

content: The room's original owner, the Duc de Crillon, signed the Treaty of Paris with Benjamin Franklin in the larger Hôtel de Crillon in 1783.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Room from the Hôtel de Crillon'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/202996

content: The room was designed by the architect Pierre-Adrien Pâris, a leading figure of the early Neoclassical style in the 1770s.
source: Whitehead, John. 'The French Interior in the Eighteenth Century.' Dutton Studio Books, 1993.

content: The boy's haircut, with its distinctive long locks at the back, was a fashionable style for elite Roman youths in the 1st century A.D.
source: Kleiner, Diana E. E. 'Roman Sculpture.' Yale University Press, 1992.

content: The statue's eyes, now empty, were originally inlaid with materials like glass paste or semi-precious stones to give it a lifelike appearance.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Bronze statue of a boy'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/248891

content: The statue was discovered in 1894 in a vineyard on the island of Rhodes, where it had been buried for centuries.
source: Mattusch, Carol C. 'Greek Bronze Statuary: From the Beginnings Through the Fifth Century B.C.' Cornell University Press, 1988.

content: This marble palmette served as an akroterion, a decorative ornament placed on the corner or peak of the roof of a funerary monument.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Marble palmette'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/250951

content: The palmette design, based on the fan-shaped leaves of a palm tree, was a popular motif in ancient Greek and Roman art and architecture.
source: Boardman, John. 'Greek Art.' Thames & Hudson, 2016.

content: This column comes from the Temple of Artemis at Sardis, which was one of the largest Greek temples ever built.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Marble column from the Temple of Artemis at Sardis'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/252453

content: Construction on the temple began in the Hellenistic period around 300 B.C. but was not completed until the Roman era, 400 years later.
source: Yegül, Fikret. 'The Bath-Gymnasium Complex at Sardis.' Harvard University Press, 1986.

content: The temple was located in present-day Turkey and was excavated by an American archaeological expedition that began in 1910.
source: Hanfmann, George M. A. 'Sardis from Prehistoric to Roman Times.' Harvard University Press, 1983.

content: This incense burner is one of the earliest securely dated objects from Islamic Iran due to the clear inscription of its patron and date.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Incense Burner of Amir Saif al-Dunya wa'l-Din'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/451042

content: The intricate openwork design allowed the aromatic smoke from burning incense, such as frankincense or oud, to escape.
source: Ettinghausen, Richard, Oleg Grabar, and Marilyn Jenkins-Madina. 'Islamic Art and Architecture, 650-1250.' Yale University Press, 2001.

content: The room's walls are inscribed with poetry comparing the room to a paradise, but also hinting at the impermanence of life and beauty.
source: Kenney, Ellen. 'The Damascus Room and the Development of the Syrian Domestic Interior.' Ars Orientalis, vol. 38, 2010.

content: The room was installed in the home of a wealthy Jewish family in Damascus, showing the cultural synthesis in the Ottoman Empire.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Damascus Room'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/452102

content: The painted panels depict not just floral motifs but also cityscapes of Damascus and architectural views, offering a window into the 18th-century city.
source: Rabbat, Nasser. 'The Damascus Room and the Historiography of the 'Islamic' Interior.' International Journal of Islamic Architecture, 2016.

content: Riza-yi 'Abbasi famously left the Shah's court for a period to associate with wrestlers and commoners, a rebellious act for a court artist.
source: Canby, Sheila R. 'The Rebellious Reformer: The Drawings and Paintings of Riza-yi 'Abbasi of Isfahan.' Azimuth Editions, 1996.

content: The painting exemplifies the 'Isfahan style,' which focused on elegant, isolated figures of youthful lovers, dandies, and mystics.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Lovers'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/451023

content: A mihrab is a niche in the wall of a mosque that indicates the qibla, the direction of the Kaaba in Mecca, which Muslims face during prayer.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Mihrab (Prayer Niche)'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/449537

content: This mihrab is a masterpiece of luster-painted tilework, a difficult technique that involves a metallic pigment creating an iridescent effect.
source: Watson, Oliver. 'Persian Lustre Ware.' Faber & Faber, 1985.

content: This panel was originally part of a five-part polyptych (a multi-paneled altarpiece) for the church of Santa Maria Maggiore in Florence.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Crucifixion'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/458998

content: The gold ground of the painting was made by applying thin sheets of real gold leaf over a layer of reddish clay called 'bole'.
source: Cennini, Cennino d'Andrea. 'Il Libro dell'Arte' (The Craftsman's Handbook). Translated by Daniel V. Thompson, Jr., 1933.

content: This panel is a small fragment of a massive high altarpiece that was dismantled in the 16th century; its pieces are now scattered in museums worldwide.
source: Freuler, Gaudenz. 'Ugolino di Nerio's Santa Croce Polyptych.' Gebr. Mann Verlag, 2014.

content: The famous art historian Giorgio Vasari criticized the altarpiece in 1568, which likely led to its removal and dismemberment.
source: Vasari, Giorgio. 'Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects.' 1568.

content: The altarpiece was a major commission from the Franciscan order, one of the most powerful religious patrons in 14th-century Florence.
source: Cannon, Joanna, and André Vauchez. 'Margherita of Cortona and the Lorenzetti: Sienese Art and the Cult of a Holy Woman in Medieval Tuscany.' Penn State Press, 1999.

content: An aquamanile is a vessel for pouring water for hand-washing at the dinner table, a crucial part of medieval dining etiquette.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Aquamanile in the Form of Aristotle and Phyllis'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/459202

content: The vessel illustrates a popular medieval tale in which the philosopher Aristotle is so besotted with a woman, Phyllis, that he allows her to ride him like a horse.
source: Barnet, Peter, and Pete Dandridge. 'Lions, Dragons, & Other Beasts: Aquamanilia of the Middle Ages.' Yale University Press, 2006.

content: The window is attributed to an anonymous artist known as the 'Master of the St. Lambrecht Votive Altarpiece,' a leading figure of the 'soft style' in Vienna.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Adoration of the Magi'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/469959

content: The details, like the beards and gold patterns, were painted on the glass with a mixture of ground glass and metal oxides, then fired in a kiln to fuse them permanently.
source: Caviness, Madeline H. 'Stained Glass Windows.' Brepols Publishers, 1996.

content: This pulpit was carved by a Pisan sculptor named Biduinus, who proudly inscribed his name on the piece, a rare practice for the period.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Pulpit'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/471911

content: The panels depict scenes from the Christmas story, including the Annunciation, the Nativity, and the Adoration of the Magi.
source: Glass, Dorothy F. 'Romanesque Sculpture in Campania: Patrons, Programs, and Style.' Penn State University Press, 1992.

content: A chapter house is a building used for meetings by the canons or monks of a monastery or cathedral.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Chapter House from Notre-Dame-de-Pontaut'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/471179

content: This room was disassembled from its original location at a Cistercian abbey in Gascony, France, and re-erected at The Met Cloisters.
source: Wixom, William D. 'Medieval Art and The Cloisters.' The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1986.

content: The purchase and relocation of entire medieval rooms by American collectors like William Randolph Hearst was a common, if controversial, practice in the early 20th century.
source: Rorimer, James J. 'The Cloisters: The Building and the Collection of Medieval Art in Fort Tryon Park.' The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1963.

content: This book uses engravings of famous ancient sculptures like the Farnese Hercules to teach artists the ideal proportions of the human body.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Les proportions du corps humain'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/749592

content: Girard Audran was a member of a famous family of engravers who worked for King Louis XIV at the French Royal Academy.
source: Préaud, Maxime. 'Inventaire du fonds français: graveurs du XVIIe siècle. Tome 1, Audran.' Bibliothèque nationale, 1993.

content: The use of grids over the figures helped students learn how to accurately scale and reproduce the complex poses of classical art.
source: Goldstein, Carl. 'Teaching Art: Academies and Schools from Vasari to Albers.' Cambridge University Press, 1996.

content: Vicente Carducho's book argues that painting is a noble, intellectual art form, superior to sculpture because it can create illusions of reality.
source: Brown, Jonathan. 'Painting in Spain, 1500-1700.' Yale University Press, 1998.

content: Carducho used his book to subtly attack rivals like the young Velázquez, arguing their brand of realism lacked the intellectual foundation of true art.
source: Carducho, Vicente. 'Diálogos de la pintura.' Edited by Francisco Calvo Serraller, 1979.

content: The book was one of the first and most important art treatises published in Spain, fiercely defending the status of painters as intellectuals, not mere craftsmen.
source: Pérez Sánchez, Alfonso E. 'Pintura barroca en España (1600-1750).' Cátedra, 1992.

content: A crossbow brooch, or fibula, was a stylish and high-status fastener used to pin a cloak at the shoulder in the late Roman and early medieval periods.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Crossbow Brooch'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/466286

content: This gilded silver brooch is decorated with niello, a black metallic alloy of sulfur, copper, silver, and lead, used as an inlay on engraved metal.
source: Bierbrauer, Volker. 'Die ostgotischen Grab- und Schatzfunde in Italien.' Centro italiano di studi sull'alto Medioevo, 1975.

content: This type of ornate fibula was often a symbol of official rank, awarded by the emperor to military and civil officials.
source: Heurgon, Jacques. 'Le Trésor de Ténès.' Arts et métiers graphiques, 1958.

content: This pointer was used to follow the text of a sacred book during liturgical readings, protecting the manuscript from oily fingers.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Liturgical Pointer'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/466296

content: The intricate decoration is cloisonné enamel, a technique where thin wires are soldered to a base to create cells, which are then filled with colored enamel.
source: Wessel, Klaus. 'Byzantine Enamels.' New York Graphic Society, 1968.

content: The hand at the tip is in a gesture of blessing, adding a layer of symbolic sanctity to the act of reading the holy text.
source: Evans, Helen C., and William D. Wixom, eds. 'The Glory of Byzantium.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1997.

content: This piece was used for the medieval board game 'Tables,' an ancestor of modern backgammon.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Game Piece with the Story of Apollonius of Tyre'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/466289

content: The carving illustrates a scene from the 'History of Apollonius of Tyre,' a popular romance story from the late Roman Empire.
source: Gaborit-Chopin, Danielle. 'Ivoires du Moyen Âge.' Fribourg, Office du Livre, 1978.

content: The game piece is carved from elephant ivory, a highly prized luxury material in medieval Europe, imported from Africa.
source: Mann, Vivian B. 'Treasures of The Jewish Museum.' Universe Books, 1986.

content: Andrea Amati is considered the father of the modern violin, having established the instrument's form and proportions in Cremona, Italy.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Violin, 'The King''. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/503517

content: This is one of a set of 38 string instruments ordered by King Charles IX of France, and his coat of arms is painted on the back.
source: Pollens, Stewart. 'The Violin Forms of Antonio Stradivari.' Biddulph, 1992.

content: The violin's varnish, a closely guarded secret, is not just for protection but is crucial to the instrument's unique resonant sound.
source: Beare, Charles. 'Antonio Stradivari: The Cremona Exhibition of 1987.' J & A Beare, 1987.

content: This instrument is a 'gallery organ,' designed to be installed in the gallery or choir loft of a church.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Organ'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/503670

content: Thomas Appleton was a leading organ builder in 19th-century Boston, a major center for American musical instrument making.
source: Owen, Barbara. 'The Organ in New England.' Sunbury Press, 1979.

content: The ornate gilded facade pipes are purely decorative; the sound-producing pipes are hidden inside the organ case.
source: Ochse, Orpha. 'The History of the Organ in the United States.' Indiana University Press, 1975.

content: This is the oldest surviving piano in the world, built by the instrument's inventor, Bartolomeo Cristofori, in Florence.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Grand Piano'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/501788

content: Cristofori named his invention 'gravicembalo col piano e forte' (harpsichord with soft and loud), as it was the first keyboard that could control volume.
source: Pollens, Stewart. 'The Early Pianoforte.' Cambridge University Press, 1995.

content: Despite its revolutionary design, Cristofori's piano was largely ignored in his lifetime, treated more as a mechanical curiosity than a serious instrument.
source: Good, Edwin M. 'Giraffes, Black Dragons, and Other Pianos.' Stanford University Press, 2001.

content: This photograph was taken at the United States Army General Hospital in Washington, D.C., to document the new field of military surgery.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Disabled Soldiers'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/302362

content: The image is an albumen silver print, the most common photographic printing process from the 1850s through the 1890s.
source: Reilly, James M. 'Care and Identification of 19th-Century Photographic Prints.' Eastman Kodak, 1986.

content: Such photographs were used to train surgeons and to design better prosthetic limbs for the vast number of amputees from the Civil War.
source: Otis, George A. 'The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion.' U.S. Government Printing Office, 1870.

content: Degas took up photography late in life, often using his friends as models and staging them in dramatic, lamp-lit interior scenes.
source: Daniel, Malcolm. 'Edgar Degas, Photographer.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998.

content: This gelatin silver print was made by Degas from his own glass negative, showing his hands-on approach to the new medium.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Artist's Room at the Rue de Douai'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/263608

content: The composition, with its cropped figures and unusual angles, is directly influenced by Degas's own impressionist paintings and Japanese prints.
source: Shackelford, George T.M. 'Degas and the Nude.' Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, 2011.

content: Frederick Douglass was the most photographed American of the 19th century, sitting for portraits more often than even Abraham Lincoln.
source: Stauffer, John, Zoe Trodd, and Celeste-Marie Bernier. 'Picturing Frederick Douglass.' Liveright, 2015.

content: Douglass deliberately used photography to counter the racist caricatures of African Americans common in his time, presenting himself with dignity and seriousness.
source: Gates, Henry Louis, Jr. 'The Black Church: This Is Our Story, This Is Our Song.' Penguin Press, 2021.

content: A daguerreotype is a unique, direct-positive image on a silver-coated copper plate, meaning there is no negative and each one is a one-of-a-kind object.
source: Newhall, Beaumont. 'The Daguerreotype in America.' Dover Publications, 1976.

content: Umberto Boccioni was a leading member of the Italian Futurists, who celebrated the speed, dynamism, and machinery of the modern city.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'The Street Pavers'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/485555

content: A passionate nationalist, Boccioni enlisted in the army during WWI but died tragically at 33, not in battle, but after falling from his horse during training.
source: Coen, Ester. 'Umberto Boccioni.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1988.

content: The high viewpoint of the painting, looking directly down on the workers, was a radical departure from traditional landscape perspective.
source: Tisdall, Caroline, and Angelo Bozzolla. 'Futurism.' Thames & Hudson, 1977.

content: Jeanne Hébuterne was Modigliani's common-law wife and muse; tragically, she took her own life the day after the artist died from meningitis.
source: Rose, June. 'Amedeo Modigliani: His Life and Work.' University of California Press, 1982.

content: Modigliani's signature elongated necks and mask-like faces show the profound influence of African sculpture, which he saw in Parisian museums.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Jeanne Hébuterne'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/488903

content: Modigliani sold his paintings for only a few francs to survive, often trading them for meals or drinks in the cafes of Montparnasse.
source: Werner, Alfred. 'Modigliani the Sculptor.' Arts, 1962.

content: Boccioni's sculpture was so radical that early critics called it a 'mangled corpse,' misunderstanding its attempt to depict motion.
source: Tisdall, Caroline, and Angelo Bozzolla. 'Futurism.' Thames & Hudson, 1977.

content: The original work was a plaster sculpture; this bronze version was not cast until 1931, long after Boccioni's death in World War I.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Unique Forms of Continuity in Space'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/485540

content: The sculpture appears on the Italian 20-cent euro coin, cementing its status as a national icon of modern art.
source: European Central Bank. 'Italy - National sides of euro coins'.

content: Leutze painted 'Washington Crossing the Delaware' in Germany, not America, using the Rhine River as a stand-in for the Delaware.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Washington Crossing the Delaware.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11417

content: The flag in the painting is historically inaccurate—this version of the Stars and Stripes wasn’t adopted until after the crossing.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Washington Crossing the Delaware.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11417

content: Leutze intended the painting as pro-democracy propaganda to inspire revolutionaries in 19th-century Europe.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Washington Crossing the Delaware.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11417

content: Rogers chose the biblical figure Ruth because she embodied ideal Victorian feminine virtues: humility and modesty.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Ruth Gleaning.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11952

content: Though Rogers sculpted the clay model himself, Italian artisans completed the final marble carving in Carrara.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Ruth Gleaning.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11952

content: The sculpture's immense popularity led to it being widely reproduced in small, affordable plaster versions for middle-class homes.
source: Tolles, Thayer. 'American Sculpture in The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Vol. 1.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1999.

content: The original painting of Madame X caused a scandal when first exhibited due to the fallen strap on her dress.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Madame X.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/12127

content: After the backlash, Sargent repainted the strap to sit properly on her shoulder to appease critics.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Madame X.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/12127

content: Sargent kept the painting for over 30 years after the scandal, considering it his masterpiece and calling it 'the best thing I have done.'
source: Davis, Deborah. 'Strapless: John Singer Sargent and the Fall of Madame X.' TarcherPerigee, 2004.

content: Henry II's ceremonial armor was never used in battle—it was meant to impress during parades and jousts.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Armor of Henry II of France.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/24671

content: The gold and silver inlays on the armor were engraved using acid etching, a rare and luxurious technique at the time.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Armor of Henry II of France.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/24671

content: The armor's intricate decorations feature Roman gods like Apollo and Minerva, intended to equate the French king with classical heroes.
source: LaRocca, Donald J. 'The Academy of the Sword: Illustrated Fencing Books, 1500–1800.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998.

content: The multiple arms and heads on Hevajra symbolize tantric transformation and omnipresent wisdom.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Hevajra.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/38304

content: Khmer artisans polished sandstone with powdered stone and bamboo to achieve the soft surface finish.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. “Hevajra.” https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/38304

content: The sculpture was likely intentionally broken and buried during a Hindu revival under King Jayavarman VIII, who sought to erase Buddhist imagery.
source: Jessup, Helen Ibbitson, and Thierry Zéphir. 'Sculpture of Angkor and Ancient Cambodia: Millennium of Glory.' National Gallery of Art, 1997.

content: The 'On Liberty' suit was part of Westwood's Autumn/Winter 1990–91 'Portrait' collection, inspired by 18th-century paintings at the Wallace Collection.
source: Victoria and Albert Museum. 'On Liberty' Ensemble. https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O75253/on-liberty-ensemble-westwood-vivienne/

content: The text from John Stuart Mill's essay is screen-printed onto the suit's lining, making it a hidden manifesto for the wearer.
source: Wilcox, Claire. 'Vivienne Westwood.' V&A Publishing, 2004.

content: The suit's traditional Prince of Wales check pattern was deliberately chosen to be subverted by the deconstructed, punk-influenced tailoring.
source: Bolton, Andrew. 'Anglomania: Tradition and Transgression in British Fashion.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2006.

content: To master anatomy, Barye obsessively studied and dissected animal carcasses from the menagerie at the Jardin des Plantes in Paris.
source: Ben-Amos, D. 'Animals in a Bourgeois World.' Daedalus, vol. 119, no. 4, 1990, pp. 171–94.

content: The specific mythological event depicted comes from Ovid's 'Metamorphoses,' describing a battle at a Lapith wedding feast.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Theseus Fighting the Centaur Bianor.' https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/186832

content: The work was a commercial success, cast in multiple sizes for private collectors by the famed Barbedienne foundry in Paris.
source: Poletti, Michel, and Alain Richarme. 'Barye: Catalogue Raisonné des Sculptures.' Gallimard, 2000.

content: The muscular physique was not idealized; it was based on a real person, a military officer and athlete named Commandant Doyen-Parigot.
source: Musée Bourdelle. 'Héraklès archer.' https://www.bourdelle.paris.fr/en/work/herakles-archer

content: Bourdelle worked as Rodin’s assistant for 15 years, and this sculpture is seen as his decisive stylistic break from his master.
source: Curtis, Penelope. 'Sculpture 1900-1945: After Rodin.' Oxford University Press, 1999.

content: The sculpture's taut, geometric forms are considered a major precursor to the stylized visual language of the Art Deco movement.
source: Jianou, Ionel, and Michel Dufet. 'Bourdelle.' Arted, Éditions d'Art, 1978.

content: Houdon first exhibited a life-size plaster version at the 1787 Salon, which created a sensation and led to commissions for marble and bronze versions.
source: Scherf, Guilhem. 'Houdon 1741-1828: Sculpteur des Lumières.' Réunion des Musées Nationaux, 2004.

content: The pose directly references the ancient Roman 'Crouching Venus' statue, but reinterprets it as a response to cold rather than modesty.
source: Poulet, Anne L. 'Jean-Antoine Houdon: Sculptor of the Enlightenment.' National Gallery of Art, 2003.

content: The original commission was for a set of the Four Seasons by the Duc de Chartres, but the project was abandoned after only Winter and Summer were modeled.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Winter.' https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/202614

content: Canova’s Perseus was inspired by the ancient Apollo Belvedere statue, which Napoleon looted for France in 1797.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/204758

content: The statue’s execution involved a pointing machine to transfer measurements from Canova’s clay model to marble.
source: Avery, Charles. 'Antonio Canova: Sculptor of Light and Marble.' Abbeville Press, 2007.

content: The statue was once housed in the Vatican but later sold to a Polish countess and ended up in the United States.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/204758

content: Bernini sculpted this piece at just 17 years old under the patronage of Cardinal Scipione Borghese.
source: Wittkower, Rudolf. 'Gian Lorenzo Bernini: The Sculptor of the Roman Baroque.' Phaidon, 1997.

content: The subject—a faun teased by children—was likely chosen to demonstrate Bernini’s virtuosity in rendering emotion and movement.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/206399

content: The sculpture has undergone significant restoration; the faun’s left arm and the upper child’s right foot are later additions.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'A Faun Teased by Children'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/206399

content: Paris holds the golden apple in this statue, a reference to the mythological Judgment of Paris that sparked the Trojan War.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/211505

content: This marble figure was carved in Canova’s workshop around 1822–23 after an earlier prototype.
source: Avery, Charles. 'Antonio Canova: Sculptor of Light and Marble.' Abbeville Press, 2007.

content: The first version of this statue was commissioned by Napoleon's ex-wife, Joséphine de Beauharnais, for her collection at Malmaison.
source: Johns, Christopher M.S. 'Antonio Canova and the Politics of Patronage in Revolutionary and Napoleonic Europe.' University of California Press, 1998.

content: Bertrand’s 'Lucretia' captures the Roman heroine moments before her suicide, a gesture that helped end the Roman monarchy.
source: Livy, 'Ab urbe condita', Book 1.

content: The sculpture was exhibited at the Paris Salon in 1704, showcasing Louis XIV-era ideals of civic virtue through tragedy.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/212215

content: The sculpture's blend of classical subject matter with intense, theatrical emotion is typical of the late Baroque style under Louis XIV.
source: Souchal, François. 'French Sculptors of the 17th and 18th Centuries: The Reign of Louis XIV.' Cassirer, 1977.

content: This Roman marble Hercules adapts a lost bronze by Lysippos, sculptor to Alexander the Great.
source: Pliny the Elder, 'Natural History', Book 34.

content: Traces of ancient pigments inside the statue’s hair suggest it was once vividly painted.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/247000

content: The statue was excavated in 1790 from the ruins of what is believed to be Emperor Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli, near Rome.
source: Haskell, Francis, and Nicholas Penny. 'Taste and the Antique: The Lure of Classical Sculpture, 1500-1900.' Yale University Press, 1981.

content: Banda masks were used in initiation ceremonies and symbolized cooperation between land and water spirits.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/310750

content: Each Banda headdress was carved from a single piece of wood and could weigh up to 25 pounds.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/310750

content: The dancer peers out through a small hole in the mask's crocodile-like jaw, while the rest of their body is concealed by a large raffia costume.
source: Lamp, Frederick John. 'Art of the Baga: A Drama of Cultural Reinvention.' Museum for African Art, 1996.

content: Dogon figures with upraised arms symbolically support the sky in their cosmology.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/310765

content: Dogon sculptures were traditionally made by blacksmiths, considered spiritually powerful within the community.
source: Griaule, Marcel. 'Conversations with Ogotemmêli.' Oxford University Press, 1965.

content: Dogon sculptors often used wood with natural cracks or insect damage, believing these imperfections imbued the object with spiritual power (nyama).
source: Ezra, Kate. 'Art of the Dogon: Selections from the Lester Wunderman Collection.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1988.

content: Jipae masks represent the spirits of the dead during Asmat funerary rituals.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/311741

content: The inflated chest design of the mask reflects vitality and life-force returning temporarily to the dancer.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/311741

content: The pigments used are all locally sourced: white is from crushed seashells, red from ochre, and black from charcoal.
source: Rockefeller, Michael Clark, and Adrian A. Gerbrands. 'The Asmat of New Guinea: The Journal of Michael Clark Rockefeller.' Museum of Primitive Art, 1967.

content: The pendant honors Queen Mother Idia, who played a crucial political role in 16th-century Benin.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/318622

content: Faces of Portuguese soldiers and mudfish around the crown symbolize trade and spiritual authority.
source: Ben-Amos, Paula. 'The Art of Benin.' British Museum Press, 1995.

content: The two vertical iron inlays on the forehead represent scarification marks that identified her as a powerful spiritual practitioner.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Queen Mother Pendant Mask: Iyoba'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/318622

content: This Assyrian lamassu was designed with five legs to appear standing from the front and walking from the side.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/322608

content: Paint traces suggest it was once vividly colored in reds and blues.
source: Curtis, John. 'Ancient Persia.' British Museum Press, 1990.

content: The cuneiform inscription running across its body is a standard text boasting of the king's titles, lineage, and military conquests.
source: Russell, John Malcolm. 'The Final Sack of Nineveh: The Discovery, Documentation, and Destruction of King Sennacherib's Palace.' Yale University Press, 1998.

content: David based 'The Death of Socrates' on Plato’s account in 'Phaedo,' capturing the philosopher's final moment with precision.
source: Plato, 'Phaedo'; Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/436105

content: David painted the work in 1787, just two years before the French Revolution began.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/436105

content: David deliberately included the figure of Plato at the foot of the bed for symbolic reasons, even though Plato was not actually present at the execution.
source: Vidal, Mary. 'David's 'Lictors Bringing to Brutus the Bodies of His Sons'.' The Art Bulletin, vol. 73, no. 4, 1991.

content: Monet was his own landscape architect, diverting a local river to create the water lily pond he would famously paint.
source: Tucker, Paul Hayes. 'Monet in the '90s: The Series Paintings.' Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, 1990.

content: This painting is one of 18 distinct views of the same bridge that Monet created during the summer of 1899 alone.
source: Wildenstein, Daniel. 'Monet or The Triumph of Impressionism.' Taschen, 1999. (Catalogue Raisonné)

content: The iconic Japanese-style bridge was not imported; it was custom-built to Monet's specifications by a local Giverny carpenter.
source: House, John. 'Monet: Nature into Art.' Yale University Press, 1986.

content: The four figures depicted are not anonymous; they are Monet's own family members, including his father, Adolphe, in the panama hat.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Garden at Sainte-Adresse.' https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/437133

content: The painting's high viewpoint and flattened spatial arrangement were directly inspired by the Japanese ukiyo-e prints Monet had begun to collect.
source: Tucker, Paul Hayes. 'Monet at Argenteuil.' Yale University Press, 1982.

content: Monet submitted this work to the 1867 Salon exhibition but it was rejected, forcing him to show it at an independent show instead.
source: Rewald, John. 'The History of Impressionism.' Museum of Modern Art, 1973.

content: Art historians widely believe Vermeer used a camera obscura, a precursor to the photographic camera, to perfect the painting's light and perspective.
source: Steadman, Philip. 'Vermeer's Camera: Uncovering the Truth behind the Masterpieces.' Oxford University Press, 2001.

content: The large map hanging on the wall was a real map of the Seventeen Provinces of the Netherlands and appears in three other Vermeer paintings.
source: Wheelock Jr., Arthur K. 'Vermeer and the Art of Painting.' Yale University Press, 1995.

content: The woman's elaborate hairstyle, with its ribbons and ringlets, was known as a 'coiffure à la négligence,' or 'careless' style.
source: Franits, Wayne. 'Vermeer.' Phaidon Press, 2015.

content: This screen was carved from a single, massive slab of red sandstone, a feat requiring the removal of more than 80% of the original stone.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Jali (Screen)'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/453344

content: The complex pattern is not just decorative; it's a tessellating geometric design based on repeating hexagons and twelve-pointed stars.
source: Koch, Ebba. 'Mughal Architecture: An Outline of Its History and Development.' Prestel, 1991.

content: The geometric perforations were designed to cast complex, shifting shadows on the floor, creating a dynamic spiritual metaphor for divine light.
source: Nath, R. 'History of Mughal Architecture, Vol. II.' Abhinav Publications, 1985.

content: The artist, Claus de Werve, was the nephew and main assistant of Claus Sluter, the most celebrated sculptor of the Burgundian court.
source: Nash, Susie. 'Northern Renaissance Art.' Oxford University Press, 2008.

content: The elegant, S-shaped curve of the Virgin's body is a defining characteristic of the courtly 'International Gothic' style.
source: Barnet, Peter, and Pete Dandridge. 'Lions, Dragons, & Other Beasts: Aquamanilia of the Middle Ages.' Yale University Press, 2006.

content: Scientific analysis reveals traces of polychromy, indicating the limestone sculpture was originally brightly painted and gilded to appear lifelike.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Virgin and Child'. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/467594

content: The cloister fragments were purchased in France by American sculptor George Grey Barnard, whose collection formed the original core of The Met Cloisters.
source: Barnard, George Grey, and Tanja Konsinski. 'George Grey Barnard: The Collector.' Goetz, 1989.

content: The original abbey at Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert was badly damaged during the French Revolution, which led to its sculptures being sold off.
source: Stokstad, Marilyn, and Michael W. Cothren. 'Art History.' Pearson, 2011.

content: Many of the capitals are carved with acanthus leaves, a motif borrowed directly from ancient Roman Corinthian columns, showing a classical influence.
source: Little, Charles T. 'The Art of Medieval Spain, A.D. 500-1200.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1993.

content: Marie-Thérèse Walter was only 17 when Picasso met her outside a Paris department store — he was 45 and still married.
source: Umland, Anne, et al. 'Picasso 1932: Love, Fame, Tragedy.' Tate Modern, 2018.

content: Picasso painted over 100 portraits of Marie-Thérèse Walter during their relationship, many kept hidden from his wife and public view.
source: McCully, Marilyn. 'A Picasso Affair.' Apollo Magazine, July 2018.

content: The portrait's sensual, biomorphic forms and dreamlike atmosphere show Picasso's deep engagement with the Surrealist movement.
source: Rubin, William S. 'Picasso and Portraiture: Representation and Transformation.' Museum of Modern Art, 1996.

content: Picasso reworked Gertrude Stein’s face 80 times before finally painting it from imagination after she left for a trip.
source: Richardson, John. 'A Life of Picasso: The Cubist Rebel, 1907–1916.' Knopf, 2021.

content: Although Americans hated the portrait, Matisse praised it — and it helped launch Picasso’s Cubist period.
source: Cowan, Sarah. 'Picasso’s Gertrude Stein: A Modern Muse.' The Met, 2020.

content: When someone remarked that she didn't look like the portrait, Stein famously replied, 'She will.'
source: Stein, Gertrude. 'The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas.' Harcourt, Brace and Company, 1933.

content: Jackson Pollock used hardened brushes, sticks, and even turkey basters to drip paint across unprimed canvas.
source: Naifeh, Steven and Gregory White Smith. 'Jackson Pollock: An American Saga.' Clarkson Potter, 1990.

content: Pollock once said, 'I am nature,' defending his method of channeling unconscious forces through physical motion.
source: Pollock, Jackson. Quoted in 'Jackson Pollock: Interviews, Articles, and Reviews.' MoMA, 1999.

content: Pollock painted it by laying the massive canvas on his barn floor, allowing him to walk around it and apply paint from all sides.
source: Varnedoe, Kirk, and Pepe Karmel. 'Jackson Pollock.' Museum of Modern Art, 1998.

content: ‘Young Sailor II’ was so stylized that Matisse’s dealer thought the canvas had been stolen and replaced by a prank.
source: Spurling, Hilary. 'Matisse the Master.' Knopf, 2005.

content: The model was an 18-year-old fisherman from the French seaside village of Collioure, where Matisse spent the summer of 1906.
source: Spurling, Hilary. 'The Unknown Matisse: A Life of Henri Matisse, Vol. 1, 1869-1908.' Knopf, 1998.

content: This is the second of two versions; the first, 'Young Sailor I,' is far more naturalistic, revealing Matisse's rapid evolution toward radical color.
source: Flam, Jack. 'Matisse: The Man and His Art, 1869-1918.' Cornell University Press, 1986.

content: The 'Breasted Drum' was used in social dance clubs in Ghana during the 1930s–40s, blending traditional carving with nightlife culture.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Object Page: 503220. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/503220

content: Carved breasts on the drum signified female protection and fertility in Akan culture, even when repurposed for entertainment.
source: Cole, Herbert M. 'African Art and Leadership.' University of Wisconsin Press, 1989.

content: The drum is attributed to the master carver Osei Bonsu, one of the most famous and influential Asante artists of the 20th century.
source: Ross, Doran H. 'The Art of Osei Bonsu.' African Arts, vol. 40, no. 1, 2007, pp. 58-71.

content: Hatshepsut ruled Egypt as a king, not a queen, often depicted with a beard and masculine regalia to reinforce her authority.
source: Tyldesley, Joyce. 'Hatchepsut: The Female Pharaoh.' Penguin Books, 1998.

content: Most of Hatshepsut’s statues were smashed by her stepson Thutmose III in a campaign to erase her legacy.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 'Hatshepsut: From Queen to Pharaoh.' 2005.

content: The sphinx's red granite was quarried in Aswan, hundreds of miles away, and transported down the Nile to her temple complex.
source: Roehrig, Catharine H., et al. 'Hatshepsut: From Queen to Pharaoh.' Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2005.

content: Kurukulla’s image was considered so powerful that it was used to magnetize both political allies and spiritual converts.
source: Beer, Robert. 'The Encyclopedia of Tibetan Symbols and Motifs.' Serindia, 2003.

content: This thangka is not painted but is an appliqué, meticulously stitched together from hundreds of pieces of colored silk.
source: Jackson, David Paul, and Janice A. Jackson. 'Tibetan Thangka Painting: Methods & Materials.' Serindia Publications, 1984.

content: Her mantra, 'Om Kurukulle Svaha,' is chanted by practitioners to invoke her powers of enchantment and subjugation for spiritual purposes.
source: Shaw, Miranda. 'Buddhist Goddesses of India.' Princeton University Press, 2006.

content: Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux carved the words 'Why born a slave!' directly into the bust, turning sculpture into protest.
source: Blundell, Claire. 'Carpeaux and the Politics of Form.' Getty Research Journal, 2017.

content: When first exhibited, the sculpture shocked Paris audiences with its realism and anti-slavery message — just 20 years after emancipation.
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Object Page: 824469. https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/824469

content: This bust was created as a study for the allegorical figure of Africa in Carpeaux's monumental 'Fountain of the Four Parts of the World' in Paris.
source: Wagner, Anne M. 'Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux: Sculptor of the Second Empire.' Yale University Press, 1986.
